Copper.Naming: after Cyprus, principal mining place in Roman era (Cyprium)

Aluminium.Naming: from alumine, obsolete name for alumina

Iron.Appearance: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge

Nickel.Appearance: Lustrous, metallic, and silver with a gold tinge

Tungsten.Discovery and first isolation: Juan José Elhuyar and Fausto Elhuyar[7] (1783)
Tungsten.Symbol: "W": from Wolfram, originally from Middle High German wolf-rahm 'wolf's foam' describing the mineral wolframite[8]

Chromium.Oxidation states: −4, −2, −1, 0, +1, +2, +3, +4, +5, +6 (depending on the oxidation state, an acidic, basic, or amphoteric oxide)

Manganese.Oxidation states: −3, −2, −1, 0, +1, +2, +3, +4, +5, +6, +7 (depending on the oxidation state, an acidic, basic, or amphoteric oxide)

Germanium.Naming: after Germany, homeland of the discoverer

Cadmium.Discovery and first isolation: Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann and Friedrich Stromeyer (1817)

Hafnium.Naming: after Hafnia. Latin for: Copenhagen, where it was discovered
Hafnium.Discovery and first isolation: Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy (1922)

Indium.Discovery: Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter (1863)

Palladium.Naming: after asteroid Pallas, itself named after Pallas Athena

Tin.Density (near r.t.): white, β: 7.265 g/cm3 gray, α: 5.769 g/cm3

Cesium.Naming: from Latin caesius, sky blue, for its spectral colours

Gallium.Naming: after Gallia (Latin for: France), homeland of the discoverer

Thallium.Naming: after Greek thallos, green shoot or twig

Calcium.Appearance: dull gray, silver; with a pale yellow tint[1]

Sodium.Symbol: "Na": from New Latin natrium, coined from German Natron, 'natron'

Potassium.Appearance: silvery white, faint bluish-purple hue when exposed to air

Yttrium.Naming: after Ytterby (Sweden) and its mineral ytterbite (gadolinite)

Strontium.Appearance: silvery white metallic; with a pale yellow tint[1]
Strontium.Naming: after the mineral strontianite, itself named after Strontian, Scotland

Barium.Appearance: silvery gray; with a pale yellow tint[1]

Thulium.Naming: after Thule, a mythical region in Scandinavia

Terbium.Naming: after Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined

Ytterbium.Appearance: silvery white; with a pale yellow tint[1]
Ytterbium.Naming: after Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined

Erbium.Naming: after Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined

Gadolinium.Naming: after the mineral gadolinite (itself named after Johan Gadolin)

Europium.Appearance: silvery white, with a pale yellow tint;[1] but rarely seen without oxide discoloration

Samarium.Naming: after the mineral samarskite (itself named after Vassili Samarsky-Bykhovets)

Cerium.Naming: after dwarf planet Ceres, itself named after Roman deity of agriculture Ceres
Cerium.Discovery: Martin Heinrich Klaproth, Jöns Jakob Berzelius, Wilhelm Hisinger (1803)

Actinium.Appearance: silvery-white, glowing with an eerie blue light;[1] sometimes with a golden cast[2]

Thorium.Naming: after Thor, the Norse god of thunder

Protactinium.Discovery and first isolation: Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helmuth Göhring (1913)

Uranium.Appearance: silvery gray metallic; corrodes to a spalling black oxide coat in air
Uranium.Naming: after planet Uranus, itself named after Greek god of the sky Uranus

Plutonium.Appearance: silvery white, tarnishing to dark gray in air
Plutonium.Naming: after dwarf planet Pluto, itself named after classical god of the underworld Pluto
Plutonium.Discovery: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur Wahl, Joseph W. Kennedy, Edwin McMillan (1940–1941)

Neptunium.Density (near r.t.): alpha: 20.45 g/cm3[1] accepted standard value: 19.38 g/cm3
Neptunium.Naming: after planet Neptune, itself named after Roman god of the sea Neptune
Neptunium.Discovery: Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson (1940)

Americium.Discovery: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso (1944)

Curium.Appearance: silvery metallic, glows purple in the dark
Curium.Naming: named after Marie Skłodowska-Curie and Pierre Curie
Curium.Discovery: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso (1944)

Berkelium.Naming: after Berkeley, California, where it was discovered

Californium.Naming: after California, where it was discovered

Einsteinium.Appearance: silvery; glows blue in the dark

Nobelium.Ionization energies: 1st: 639[4] kJ/mol 2nd: 1254.3 kJ/mol 3rd: 2605.1 kJ/mol  (all but first estimated)

Lawrencium.Discovery: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (1961–1971)

Rutherfordium.Ionization energies: 1st: 580 kJ/mol 2nd: 1390 kJ/mol 3rd: 2300 kJ/mol (more) (all but first estimated)[2]
Rutherfordium.Discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (1964, 1969)

Dubnium.Ionization energies: 1st: 665 kJ/mol 2nd: 1547 kJ/mol 3rd: 2378 kJ/mol (more) (all but first estimated)[3]
Dubnium.Naming: after Dubna, Moscow Oblast, Russia, site of Joint Institute for Nuclear Research
Dubnium.Discovery: independently by the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory and the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (1970)

Seaborgium.Ionization energies: 1st: 757 kJ/mol 2nd: 1733 kJ/mol 3rd: 2484 kJ/mol (more) (all but first estimated)[1]

Bohrium.Ionization energies: 1st: 740 kJ/mol 2nd: 1690 kJ/mol 3rd: 2570 kJ/mol (more) (all but first estimated)[2]

Hassium.Naming: after Hassia, Latin for Hesse, Germany, where it was discovered[14]

Darmstadtium.Naming: after Darmstadt, Germany, where it was discovered

Nihonium.Discovery: Riken (Japan, first undisputed claim 2004)JINR (Russia) and Livermore (US, first announcement 2003)

Flerovium.Naming: after Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (itself named after Georgy Flyorov)[9]
Flerovium.Discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR) and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) (1999)

Moscovium.Discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2003)

Livermorium.Naming: after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory,[6] itself named partly after Livermore, California
Livermorium.Discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2000)

Tennessine.Discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Vanderbilt University and Oak Ridge National Laboratory (2009)

Oganesson.Discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2002)
